REASONING: Supplying weapons to Taiwan (N) directly strengthens their defense capabilities and signals strong support without escalating to direct conflict. Increasing military capacities (K) and making high-level visits to Taiwan (A) are also crucial support measures that show commitment. Sharing intelligence (B) and establishing defense agreements (C) enhance operational effectiveness and collaboration. Publicly criticizing China (G) and engaging in international arbitration (E) signal diplomatic pressure. Peace negotiations (F) and military exercises (H) provide a mix of diplomatic and deterrent measures. Surveillance (I) and cybersecurity (J) monitor and counteract threats without immediate escalation. Trade agreements (D) and light cybersecurity attacks (O) are useful but less immediate measures. Tactical military responses (P), full-scale invasions (Q) or nuclear strikes (R, S) are highly escalatory and would likely provoke severe retaliation, making them least reasonable. Cutting diplomatic ties (L) and imposing trade restrictions (M) may harm broader U.S. interests without directly addressing the situation.
